Text:
You could convert each array within the array to a string and use indexOf instead to find `"0,1"`, otherwise you are strictly comparing objects and that won't work because no two objects are the same. function myFunction() { var haystack = [[0,1],[1,1],[1,2]]; var needle = [0,1] ; var stringArray = haystack.map(function(array){ return array.join(); }); // becomes ["0,1","1,1","1,2"] var a = stringArray.indexOf( needle.join() ); // "0,1" document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = a; }

Click the button to display the position of the element "[0,1]":

**Convert and compare strings** You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`map()`][1] and [`join()`][2]. Then use indexOf instead to find `"0,1"`, you are strictly comparing objects except no two objects are the same. function myFunction() { var haystack = [[0,1],[1,1],[1,2]]; var needle = [0,1]; var stringArray = haystack.map(function(array){ return array.join(); }); // becomes ["0,1","1,1","1,2"] var a = stringArray.indexOf( needle.join() ); // "0,1" document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = a; }

[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join

**Convert and compare strings** Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`map()`][1] and [`join()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] instead to find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true function myFunction() { var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var needle = [0,1]; var stringArray = haystack.map(function(array){ return array.join(); }); // becomes ["0,1","1,1","1,2"] var a = stringArray.indexOf( needle.join() ); // "0,1" document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = a; }

[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

**Convert and compare strings** Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`map()`][1] and [`join()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] instead to find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true **The outcome:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var needle = [0,1].join(); var stringArray = haystack.map(function(array){ return array.join(); }); var a = stringArray.indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = a; }

[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

**Convert and compare strings** Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`map()`][1] and [`join()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The outcome:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var myArray = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = myArray.map(function(array){ return array.join(); }); var index = haystack.indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

**Convert and compare strings** Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The outcome:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var myArray = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = myArray.join('-').split('-'); var index = haystack.indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

**Convert and compare strings** Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The outcome:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` - `.indexOf("0,1")` produces `0` [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

Convert and compare strings

Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The goal:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` - `.indexOf("0,1")` produces `0`

Abstract version

function arrayInArray(needle, haystack) { return haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf( needle.join() ); } arrayInArray([0,1], [["0,1"],["1,1"],["1,2"]]) // returns 0 [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

Convert and compare strings

Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The goal:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` - `.indexOf("0,1")` produces `0`

Abstract version

function arrayInArray(needle, haystack) { return haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf( needle.join() ); } arrayInArray([0,1], [["0,1"],["1,1"],["1,2"]]) // returns 0 [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

Convert and compare strings

Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The goal:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` - `.indexOf("0,1")` produces `0`

Abstract version

var needle = [0,1]; var haystack = [["0,1"],["1,1"],["1,2"]]; var index = getIndex(needle, haystack) // returns 0 function getIndex(needle, haystack) { return haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf( needle.join() ); } [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

Convert and compare strings

Strictly comparing objects is false because no two objects are the same. You could convert each array within the array to a string using [`join()`][1] and [`split()`][2]. Then use [`indexOf`][3] to instead find `"0,1"`. [0,1] === [0,1] // false "0,1" === "0,1" // true
**The goal:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
function myFunction() { var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ; }

- `.join('-')` produces `"0,1-1,1-1,2"` - `.split('-')` produces `["0,1", "1,1", "1,2"]` - `.indexOf("0,1")` produces `0`

Standalone Function

var needle = [0,1]; var haystack = [["0,1"],["1,1"],["1,2"]]; var index = getIndex(needle, haystack) // returns 0 function getIndex(needle, haystack) { return haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf( needle.join() ); } [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf

**The goal:** `["0,1","1,1","1,2"].indexOf("0,1")` which is the intended use of `indexOf()`
var needle = [0,1].join(); // or "0,1" var haystack = [ [0,1],[1,1],[1,2] ]; var index = haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf(needle); document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = index ;

Standalone Function

var needle = [0,1]; var haystack = [["0,1"],["1,1"],["1,2"]]; var index = getIndex(needle, haystack) // returns 0 function getIndex(needle, haystack) { return haystack.join('-').split('-').indexOf( needle.join() ); } [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf
